column4: China Southern Airlines suspends direct flight to and from UK - state media
column5: BEIJING (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines, the country’s largest airline by passenger numbers, will suspend direct flights to and from London from Dec. 24 to Jan. 7, state radio reported on Wednesday.
column6: Countries across the globe are shutting their borders to Britain after the emergence of a highly infectious new coronavirus strain.
column7: China Southern has been operating one weekly flight between its hub Guangzhou and London.

column4: China Southern Airlines suspends direct flight to and from UK - state media
column5: China Southern Airlines (600029.SS), the country's largest airline by passenger numbers, will suspend direct flights to and from London from Dec. 24 to Jan. 7, state radio reported on Wednesday.
column6: Countries across the globe are shutting their borders to Britain after the emergence of a highly infectious new coronavirus strain.
column7: China Southern has been operating one weekly flight between its hub Guangzhou and London.

column4: China Southern Airlines flight from Dhaka to Guangzhou suspended over COVID-19 cases
column5: BEIJING, June 14 (Reuters) - A China Southern Airlines flight from Dhaka to Guangzhou will be suspended for four weeks from June 22 due to concerns about COVID-19 infections, China’s aviation regulator said on Sunday.
column6: Seventeen passengers on a June 11 flight from the Bangladeshi capital to the southern Chinese city tested positive for the coronavirus, meeting the conditions for a “circuit breaker” suspension of the service, the Civil Aviation Administration of China in a statement.
column7: China reported 19 new confirmed cases involving travelers from overseas for June 13, with 17 of them arriving in Guangdong province. (Reporting by Yew Lun Tian and Stella Qiu; Editing by Sam Holmes)

column4: China Southern Airlines plans to issue up to $2.25 billion in A-share convertible bonds
column5: BEIJING (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines is planning to issue up to 16 billion yuan ($2.25 billion) in A-share convertible bonds to fund purchases of aircraft, maintenance services and spare engines, and to boost cashflows, the carrier said on Thursday.
column6: Convertible debt offers coupons - interest payments - like normal bonds, but also carries the right to convert the debt into shares at a certain price.
column7: The carrier will raise 10.6 billion yuan to buy aircraft, aviation supplies and maintenance programmes, accounting for about half of the total investment the airline needed, it said in a company filing, adding that it is also aiming to raise 600 million yuan to fund purchases of spare engines. The remaining 4.8 billion yuan will be used to boost its capital.
column8: The move came after China Southern reported an almost 300% plunge in its first-quarter net profit due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, as the carrier in March reportedly warned about the “extreme difficulties” facing business operations.
column9: Chinese airlines reported a total loss of 33.62 billion yuan ($4.8 billion) in the first quarter as the pandemic shattered travel demand.
column10: Demand, as measured by revenue passenger kilometres, was still down over 70% in March, latest data showed.

column4: BRIEF-China Southern Airlines Says In March, Passenger Capacity Of Group Decreased By 60.44%
column5: April 17 (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines Co Ltd :
column6: * IN MARCH 2020, PASSENGER CAPACITY OF GROUP DECREASED BY 60.44%
column7: * MARCH PASSENGER LOAD FACTOR 58.16%, DOWN 24.99 PERCENTAGE POINTS
column8: * IN MARCH 2020, GROUP TERMINATED LEASE OF TWO AIRCRAFT, INCLUDING ONE A330-300 AIRCRAFT AND ONE A319 AIRCRAFT
column9: * MARCH CARGO AND MAIL LOAD FACTOR WAS 69.69%, REPRESENTING AN INCREASE OF 17.46 PERCENTAGE POINTS
column10: * SEES SUBSTANTIAL LOSS FOR GROUP’S OPERATING RESULTS IN Q1 OF 2020; WILL ADVERSELY AFFECT OPERATING RESULTS IN H1 OF YEAR Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-China Southern Airlines Gets Approval On Issuance Of Overseas Listed Foreign Shares
column5: April 8 (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines Co Ltd :
column6: * RECEIVED APPROVAL ON ISSUANCE OF OVERSEAS LISTED FOREIGN SHARES ISSUED BY CSRC
column7: * CSRC APPROVED ISSUE OF NOT MORE THAN 613.4 MILLION NEW OVERSEAS LISTED FOREIGN SHARES BY CO
column8: * ALL ORDINARY SHARES HAVE NOMINAL VALUE OF RMB1 PER SHARE Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-China Southern Airlines Gets CSRC's Acceptance Notice Of Application For Administration Permission
column5: Feb 11 (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines Co Ltd :
column6: * GETS “CSRC’S ACCEPTANCE NOTICE OF APPLICATION FOR ADMINISTRATION PERMISSION” ISSUED BY CSRC
column7: * ACCEPTANCE NOTICE IN RELATION TO OFFSHORE ISSUANCE OF SHARES Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: China Southern Air Holding sets up one billion yuan cargo company
column5: BEIJING (Reuters) - China Southern Air Holding, the parent of China Southern Airlines 600029.SS, has set up a cargo company with registered capital of 1 billion yuan ($143 million), as it looks to consolidate its air cargo assets through state-led reforms.
column6: The move from December 24 was disclosed by a filing approved on the National Enterprise Credit Information Publicity System and comes as China prioritizes implementing mixed ownership reforms to revamp its bloated, debt-ridden state sector.
column7: China Southern is among 96 centrally owned companies supervised by the state assets regulator, the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission (SASAC).
column8: As such, China Southern Airlines would offload its old freight unit to the newly registered company, according to a statement from SASAC in October. The cargo company would also take over other air cargo assets under the parent company such as belly cargo services, cargo terminals and international logistics.
column9: The cargo business would be managed in a market-oriented way and would become a major source of profits, said the SASAC.
column10: The air cargo market, an economic bellwether linked to global trade, saw its traffic decline by 3.3% in 2019, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) said, driven by a tariff war between the United States and China.
column11: In 2017, China Eastern Air Holding 600115.SS sold almost half of its freight unit to four firms, while Air China 601111.SS last year offloaded a majority stake in its cargo arm in face of market uncertainties.

column4: China Southern to keep most SkyTeam code-share partnerships after leaving
column5: BEIJING (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines 600029.SS1055.HK will keep code-share partnerships with most SkyTeam members after its official departure from the airline alliance on Jan. 1, the airline said on Tuesday.
column6: A code-share agreement is an arrangement where two or more airlines share the same flight. A seat can be purchased from an airline on a flight that is actually operated by another airline under a different flight number or code. All major airlines have one or more code-share agreements.
column7: China Southern will continue code-share partnerships with 14 existing SkyTeam partners including Aeroflot, Air France, Delta Air Lines, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Korean Air and Xiamen Airlines, it said in a statement to Hong Kong stock exchange.
column8: Frequent flyer cooperations will also be continued with these SkyTeam partners, it said, adding the airline would launch its own priority service brand to substitute “Skypriority” on its flights.
column9: However, China Southern will not continue its code-share partnership with China Eastern Airlines Corp Ltd 600115.SS0670.HK, another SkyTeam member.
column10: China Southern said last year it was planning to leave SkyTeam, one of the three global airline alliances that provide reciprocal benefits for passengers such as lounge usage and frequent flyer points and give airlines transfer passengers from partners in a boost to revenue.
column11: SkyTeam will have 19 members after the departure of China Southern Airlines.
column12: After it announced plans to leave the alliance, China Southern has expanded its code-sharing deal with British Airways and deepened cooperations with American Airlines AAL.O, both members of the Oneworld group of airlines which China Southern could look to join at a later date.

column4: China Southern will maintain codeshare partnerships with SkyTeam members after departure
column5: BEIJING, Dec 24 (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines will maintain the codeshare partnerships with existing SkyTeam members after its official departure from the alliance on Jan. 1 next year, the airline said on Tuesday.
column6: Frequent flyer cooperations will also be continued with SkyTeam partners, China Southern said in a stock filing, adding that the carrier would launch its own priority service brand to substitute “Skypriority” on its flights.
column7: The carrier said last year that it was planning to depart the SkyTeam, one of the three global airline alliances that provide reciprocal benefits for passengers such as lounge usage and frequent flyer points and give airlines transfer passengers from partners in a boost to revenue.
column8: After it announced plans to leave the alliance, China Southern has expanded its code-sharing deal with British Airways and deepened cooperations with American Airlines, both members of the Oneworld group of airlines which China Southern could look to join at a later date. (Reporting by Stella Qiu and Brenda Goh, editing by Louise Heavens and Louise Heavens)

column4: British Airways, China Southern expand code-sharing deal
column5: LONDON (Reuters) - British Airways and China Southern Airlines 600029.SS1055.HK have expanded their code-sharing deal with a view to boosting tourism between the two countries.
column6: The two carriers said on Tuesday their new joint business agreement would enable them to cooperate more on scheduling and pricing, open up more destinations between the two countries and develop a combined route network from Beijing’s new airport.
column7: The pair, which have had a code-sharing deal since 2017, will now code-share on all direct flights operated between London and the Chinese cities of Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Sanya, Wuhan and Zhengzhou.
column8: Code-sharing allows two or more carriers to publish and advertise tickets on the same plane under different flight numbers, helping to reduce the number of empty seats on flights.
column9: Alex Cruz, chairman and CEO of British Airways, part of the IAG ICAG.L group of airlines, said the deal would benefit customers.
column10: “The agreement reinforces our commitment to boost tourism and business travel between the two countries and we look forward to strengthening the relationship further,” he said in a statement.
column11: China Southern also has a strategic partnership with American Airlines Group Inc AAL.O.
column12: American and British Airways are both members of the Oneworld group of airlines which China Southern could look to join after it said it would leave rival alliance SkyTeam in 2018.
column13: Oneworld and SkyTeam are two of three global airline alliances that provide reciprocal benefits for passengers such as lounge usage and frequent flyer points and give airlines transfer passengers from partners in a boost to revenue. Star Alliance is the third.

column4: China Southern Airlines to receive $4 billion capital injection
column5: SHANGHAI (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines 600029.SS will carry out an equity diversification plan that will involve the injection of 30 billion yuan ($4.36 billion) of capital from three investors, the firm announced on Saturday.
column6: The Guangdong Hengjian Investment Holding Corporation, the Guangzhou Urban Construction Investment Group and the Shenzhen Penghang Equity Investment Fund will each inject 10 billion yuan into the airline, as part of the country’s efforts to diversify ownership structures among state-owned firms.
column7: The move will significantly improve the company’s debt-to-asset ratio, generate funds for its growth and help modernize its decision-making mechanisms, the announcement said.
column8: It will also use the funds to serve its main air transportation business, pay for construction related to China’s Belt and Road Initiative and support aviation development in cities in the southern province of Guangdong.
column9: China Southern is one of 96 enterprises owned and administered directly by the central government. Its profits slumped nearly 50% last year as a result of rising fuel costs and a weak yuan currency.

column4: UPDATE 1-China Southern, China Eastern Airlines post annual losses on fuel costs, weak yuan
column5: (Adds results from China Eastern Airlines)
column6: BEIJING, March 29 (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines and China Eastern Airlines on Friday both posted a slump in annual profits, hit by rising fuel costs and a weak yuan currency, missing analyst forecasts.
column7: China Southern, the country’s largest carrier by passenger numbers, said its 2018 profit attributable to shareholders fell 49.6 percent to 2.98 billion yuan ($443.59 million), compared with an average forecast of 3.81 billion yuan based on 19 analysts, according to Refinitiv data.
column8: Revenue rose 12.66 percent on the year to 143.62 billion yuan, in line with growing demand for travel in the world’s fastest-expanding aviation market.
column9: The airline warned that big fluctuations in the yuan this year, along with rising oil prices, were likely to weigh on profits in the year ahead.
column10: Foreign exchange losses amounted to 1.74 billion yuan as the yuan fell against the U.S. dollar in the 12-month period, versus a gain of 1.79 billion yuan a year earlier.
column11: The yuan fell by more than 5 percent against the U.S. dollar last year, pushing up financing costs at airlines which have bought planes with mainly U.S. dollar-denominated loans.
column12: China Eastern, the country’s second-largest carrier by passenger numbers, reported a 57 percent slump in net profit last year to 2.71 billion yuan. It missed the average forecast of 4 billion yuan from 18 analysts, according to Refinitiv data.
column13: Revenue jumped 13.0 percent year-on-year to 114.93 billion yuan, the carrier said, while incurring foreign exchange losses of 2.0 billion yuan in the 12-month period.
column14: Their main rival Air China, in contrast, posted a 1.3 percent increase in its annual net profit, outperforming analysts’ forecasts, as better passenger yields outweighed the impact of rising fuel costs and a softer yuan.
column15: A gain on its investment in Cathay Pacific Airways that reported a profit for the first time in three years also helped boost performance.
column16: Chinese airlines are among carriers worldwide that have grounded Boeing 737 MAX aircraft over safety concerns. It is still unclear whether they will have to bear any costs, analysts say.
column17: China Southern has grounded 25 737 MAX 8 aircraft while China Eastern has 4, data from flight-tracking website FlightRadar24 shows. Air China has 15 Max 8 aircraft grounded.

column4: China Southern Airlines, Emirates agree codeshare partnership
column5: SHANGHAI (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines said on Friday it signed a memorandum of understanding with Gulf carrier Emirates for a codeshare agreement.
column6: The codesharing agreement, which covers 18 flight routes, will begin on March 31, subject to approval from the Chinese aviation regulator, it said in a post on its official Weibo account.

column4: Qatar Airways acquires 5 percent of China Southern Airlines
column5: DUBAI/BEIJING (Reuters) - Qatar Airways has acquired a 5 percent stake in China Southern Airlines 600029.SS, the state-owned Gulf carrier said on Wednesday, in a move to gain access to the fast-growing mainland Chinese market.
column6: Qatar Airways also owns a 20 percent stake in British Airways-parent International Consolidated Airlines Group ICAG.L, 10 percent of South America's LATAM Airlines Group SA LTM.SN, 49 percent of Italy's Meridiana and 9.99 percent stake in Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific 0293.HK.
column7: Qatar’s flagship airline has sought new partners and routes after it was blocked last year from flying to the lucrative markets of Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates because of restrictions imposed by those countries.
column8: Saudi Arabia, UAE, Bahrain and Egypt, imposed a political and economic boycott on Qatar since June 2017, accusing it of supporting terrorism, which Doha denies.
column9: China Southern in a separate statement said Qatar Airways may consider increasing its stake in the airline in the next 12 months. Qatar had no previous investment in the Chinese airline.
column10: Qatar Airways is the second foreign carrier that has a stake in China Southern, after American Airlines AAL.O. The Chinese carrier left the Skyteam airline alliance at the start of the year.
column11: There are opportunities for “us to work together and build a long term relationship in ways that would bring benefits to customers of both airlines,” said Qatar Airways’ Chief Executive Akbar al-Baker.
column12: Ajith K, director of Asia transport at UOB Kay Hian, said given that China Southern is the biggest competitor of Cathay Pacific 0293.HK in Greater China, this deal could strengthen the China Southern's position at the Hong-Kong carrier's expense.
column13: “Why Qatar is doing, seems to me, one of course is to gain access to the Chinese market. Secondly it’s probably that they are hedging against their bet given they own almost 10 percent in Cathay Pacific.”

column4: COMAC names China Southern general manager as a deputy party boss -report
column5: SHANGHAI, Nov 26 (Reuters) - Commercial Aircraft Corp of China (COMAC) has named China Southern Airlines General Manager Tan Wangeng as a new deputy party boss, a publication run by the country’s aviation regulator reported on Monday.
column6: China Civil Aviation Magazine said on its website that the announcement was made at the Chinese state planemaker’s party committee meeting.
column7: COMAC and China Southern did not immediately respond to requests for comment. (Reporting by Brenda Goh; Editing by Muralikumar Anantharaman)

column4: China Southern to quit SkyTeam, strengthen American partnership
column5: SHANGHAI/CHICAGO (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines 600029.SS1055.HK plans to depart the SkyTeam airline alliance, it said on Thursday, opening the potential for the carrier to become a member of the oneworld group alongside strategic partner American Airlines Group Inc AAL.O.
column6: Oneworld and SkyTeam are two of three global airline alliances that provide reciprocal benefits for passengers such as lounge usage and frequent flyer points and give airlines transfer passengers from partners in a boost to revenue. Star Alliance is the third.
column7: American spent $200 million on a minority stake in China Southern last year with an eye to growing in the booming Chinese travel market, but the benefits of the partnership have been stalled in part by the Chinese carrier’s presence in rival alliance SkyTeam.
column8: China Southern said it will leave SkyTeam on Jan. 1 to develop its own strategy. It said it would strengthen its partnership with American, but did not specify any plans to join oneworld.
column9: “This news presents a great opportunity for us to continue to expand our relationship with the largest airline in China,” American Airlines said in a statement. The two companies launched a reciprocal codeshare agreement earlier this year.
column10: One source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told Reuters that China Southern would consider joining oneworld in the future.
column11: Aside from American, members of oneworld include British Airways ICAG.L, Cathay Pacific 0293.HK, Qantas Airways QAN.AX, Japan Airlines 9201.T and LATAM Airlines LTM.SN.
column12: “Our members will assess in due course the potential implications for oneworld of China Southern’s announcement today that it is to leave SkyTeam,” oneworld said in a statement.
column13: SkyTeam - which includes Delta Air Lines Inc DAL.N and Air France KLM SA AIRF.PA - has said it will work with China Southern to ensure a seamless transition for all customers and partners - a process that will run throughout 2019 and be completed by the year-end.
column14: SkyTeam already has another big Chinese carrier, China Eastern Airlines Corp Ltd 600115.SS, as a member. It is unusual to have two rival carriers within the same alliance.
column15: Xiamen Airlines Co Ltd, a subsidiary of China Southern that is also a SkyTeam member, has no plans to quit the alliance, Xiamen spokesman Qiu Dapeng said on Thursday.
column16: U.S. airlines have so far struggled to gain a foothold in China, scaling back routes amid tough competition from state-backed Chinese rivals that are aggressively expanding their fleets with cut-price tickets.
column17: Beijing plans to open its second international airport, Beijing Daxing International, in 2019.

column4: UPDATE 1-Profits fall at China Southern Airlines, Air China on weaker yuan, higher fuel costs
column5: (Adds Air China quarterly results)
column6: BEIJING, Oct 30 (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines Co Ltd and Air China on Tuesday both reported a fall in quarterly net profit, as weakness in the yuan and higher fuel and debt costs weighed on their performance.
column7: Chinese airlines have been hit by rebounding oil prices and a volatile currency, putting earnings under pressure even as they enjoy strong travel demand.
column8: China Southern Airlines, the country’s largest carrier by passenger numbers, reported profit attributable to shareholders of 2.0 billion yuan ($287 million) for the third quarter, down from 4.3 billion yuan in the same period last year.
column9: Net profit was down 41 percent for the first nine months of the year at 4.2 billion yuan, although revenue rose 13 percent to 108.9 billion yuan in the period.
column10: Air China, the country’s flag carrier, said profit attributable to shareholders for the third quarter fell to 3.5 billion yuan from 5 billion yuan over the same period last year. Net profit was down 16.2 percent for the first nine months.
column11: China Southern incurred foreign exchange losses of 2.0 billion yuan due to a drop in yuan against the U.S. dollar in the nine-month period, compared with a gain of 1.2 billion yuan a year earlier.
column12: The yuan has fallen by about 6 percent against the dollar since the start of the year, raising financing costs for airlines as their fleet expansion plans have been mostly financed by U.S. dollar-denominated loans.
column13: China Eastern Airlines Corp Ltd, the country’s second-largest airline by passenger numbers, on Friday posted a 38 percent fall in third-quarter net profit.

column4: China Southern Airlines profit halves as weaker yuan, higher fuel costs weigh
column5: BEIJING, Oct 30 (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines Co Ltd said on Tuesday its quarterly net profit more than halved, weighed down by a drop in yuan and higher fuel and debt costs.
column6: China’s airlines have been hit by rebounding oil prices and a volatile currency, which have pressured their earnings even as they enjoy strong travel demand.
column7: China Southern Airlines - the country’s largest carrier by passenger numbers - reported profit attributable to shareholders of 2.0 billion yuan ($287.42 million) for the third quarter, down from 4.3 billion yuan in the same period last year.
column8: Net profit was down 41 percent for the first nine months of the year at 4.2 billion yuan, though revenue rose 13 percent to 108.9 billion yuan in the period.
column9: The company incurred foreign exchange losses of 2.0 billion yuan due to a drop in yuan against the U.S. dollar in the nine-month period, compared with a gain of 1.2 billion yuan a year earlier.
column10: The yuan has fallen by about 6 percent against the dollar since the start of the year, raising airlines’ financing costs as their fleet expansion plans have been mostly financed by U.S. dollar-denominated loans.
column11: China Eastern Airlines Corp Ltd, the country’s second-largest airline by passenger numbers, on Friday posted a 38 percent fall in third-quarter net profit. [nL3N1WZ485 ($1 = 6.9584 Chinese yuan)

column4: China Southern Airlines plans to grow fleet to 2,000 planes by 2035: CEO
column5: SHANGHAI (Reuters) - China Southern Airlines 600029.SS1055.HK plans to more than double the size of its fleet to 2,000 aircraft by 2035 and is exploring ways to cooperate with low-cost carriers, its chief executive said at a conference on Monday.
column6: Tan Wangeng told the World Routes conference that China’s largest carrier by passenger numbers is also looking to fly to South America within the next three years, according to the official conference website.
column7: “By 2020 there will be 200 million outbound tourists from China. This provides us with a lot of opportunities for development,” Tan told the conference in Guangzhou.
column8: “We plan to have 1,000 aircraft by 2020 and by 2035 it will increase to 2,000,” he was quoted as saying.
column9: The company said last month that it had a fleet of 786 passenger and cargo aircraft at the end of June.
column10: China Southern was not immediately able to confirm Tan’s comments.
column11: Tan said the airline was looking for ways to cope with a rising number of budget carriers, especially in China and Southeast Asia where they compete for market share.
column12: “All major airlines need partners and we are looking into the possibility of establishing more joint ventures. We haven’t tried with low-cost carriers yet, but we are considering how to cooperate with them,” he said.
column13: Chinese airlines, including the firm's main rivals Air China 601111.SS0753.HK and China Eastern Airlines 600115.SS0670.HK, have been aggressively expanding their fleets and launching new routes in response to booming travel demand in the country.
column14: However, passenger returns are now falling on some routes due to stiffer competition and the impact of higher capacity.
column15: U.S. planemaker Boeing CO BA.N predicted last week that Chinese airlines will buy 7,690 new planes worth $1.2 trillion over the next two decades, higher than previously forecast.
